query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 «Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni 2 verso di noi; però dinanzi mira», 3 disse ’l maestro mio, «se tu ’l discerni».
query.result: 1 The king's banners advance of the infernal 2 toward us; however ahead looks, 3 said my master, “if you discern it”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
4 Come quando una grossa nebbia spira, 5 o quando l’emisperio nostro annotta, 6 par di lungi un molin che ’l vento gira,
7 veder mi parve un tal dificio allotta; 8 poi per lo vento mi ristrinsi retro 9 al duca mio, ché non lì era altra grotta.
query.result:
4 Like when a thick fog breathes, 5 or when our emisperio is hidden, 6 it seems from afar a mill that the wind turns,
7 to see it seemed to me such a difficulty in battle; 8 then by the wind I drew myself back 9 to my duke, because there was no other cave there.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Già era, e con paura il metto in metro, 11 là dove l’ombre tutte eran coperte, 12 e trasparien come festuca in vetro.
query.result: 10 Already it was, and with fear I set it in measure, 11 there where all the shadows were covered, 12 and they were transparent like a reed in glass.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Altre sono a giacere; altre stanno erte, 14 quella col capo e quella con le piante; 15 altra, com’ arco, il volto a’ piè rinverte.

Please translate each line literally into English.
16 Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante, 17 ch’al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi 18 la creatura ch’ebbe il bel sembiante,
19 d’innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi, 20 «Ecco Dite», dicendo, «ed ecco il loco 21 ove convien che di fortezza t’armi».
query.result:
16 When we were made so far ahead, 17 that to my master pleased to show me 18 the creature that had the beautiful semblance,
19 from before it withdrew from me and made me stay, 20 “Here say”, saying, “and here the place 21 where it is fitting that you arm yourself with a fortress”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Com’ io divenni allor gelato e fioco, 23 nol dimandar, lettor, ch’i’ non lo scrivo, 24 però ch’ogne parlar sarebbe poco.
query.result: 22 How I then became frozen and feeble, 23 Do not ask, reader, that I do not write it, 24 For every speech would be little.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Io non mori’ e non rimasi vivo; 26 pensa oggimai per te, s’hai fior d’ingegno, 27 qual io divenni, d’uno e d’altro privo.

Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Lo ’mperador del doloroso regno 29 da mezzo ’l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia; 30 e più con un gigante io mi convegno,
31 che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia: 32 vedi oggimai quant’ esser dee quel tutto 33 ch’a così fatta parte si confaccia.
query.result:
28 The emperor of the painful kingdom 29 from the middle of the chest went out of the ice; 30 and more with a giant I meet,
31 that the giants do not do with his arms: 32 see ever how much being must that whole 33 that to such a made part it fashions itself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 S’el fu sì bel com’ elli è ora brutto, 35 e contra ’l suo fattore alzò le ciglia, 36 ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto.
query.result: 34 If it was so beautiful as it is now ugly, 35 and against its maker raised the eyelashes, 36 well must from him proceed every grief.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia 38 quand’ io vidi tre facce a la sua testa! 39 L’una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia;
40 l’altr’ eran due, che s’aggiugnieno a questa 41 sovresso ’l mezzo di ciascuna spalla, 42 e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:
43 e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla; 44 la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali 45 vegnon di là onde ’l Nilo s’avvalla.

Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand’ ali, 47 quanto si convenia a tanto uccello: 48 vele di mar non vid’ io mai cotali.
query.result: 46 Under each two great wings were emerging, 47 as it was fitting for such a bird: 48 sea sails I never saw such.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello 50 era lor modo; e quelle svolazzava, 51 sì che tre venti si movean da ello:
52 quindi Cocito tutto s’aggelava.
query.result:
49 They had no feathers, but of vispistrello 50 that was their way; and those fluttered, 51 so that three winds moved from it:
52 then Cocito all was angelizing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
53 Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti 54 gocciava ’l pianto e sanguinosa bava.
55 Da ogne bocca dirompea co’ denti 56 un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla, 57 sì che tre ne facea così dolenti.
query.result:
53 With six eyes he/she wept, and for three minds 54 the tears and sanguineous drool were dripping.
55 From every mouth it burst forth with teeth 56 a sinner, in the fashion of a sack, 57 so that three made it thus sorrowful.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla 59 verso ’l graffiar, che talvolta la schiena 60 rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla.
query.result: 58 In front of that the biting was nothing 59 toward the scratching, which sometimes the back 60 remains of the skin all brown

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 «Quell’ anima là sù c’ha maggior pena», 62 disse ’l maestro, «è Giuda Scarïotto, 63 che ’l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena.
query.result: 61 That soul up there has greater pain, 62 said the master, “it is Judas Scarïotto, 63 that the head has inside and outside the legs leads.”

64 Of the other two they have the head from below, 65 the one that hangs from the black head is Bruto: 66 see how it twists, and does not make a motto!;
67 and the other is Cassio, who seems so membruto.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
68 Ma la notte risurge, e oramai 69 è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto».
70 Com’ a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai; 71 ed el prese di tempo e loco poste, 72 e quando l’ali fuoro aperte assai,
73 appigliò sé a le vellute coste; 74 di vello in vello giù discese poscia 75 tra ’l folto pelo e le gelate croste.
query.result:
68 But the night rises again, and now 69 it is to depart, because all we have seen».
70 As it pleased him, I wrapped the neck around them; 71 and he took of time and place placed, 72 and when the wings were opened much,
73 he grasped himself to the velvety ribs; 74 from fleece to fleece down descended afterwards 75 among the thick hair and the frozen crusts.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia 77 si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l’anche, 78 lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
79 volse la testa ov’ elli avea le zanche, 80 e aggrappossi al pel com’ om che sale, 81 sì che ’n inferno i’ credea tornar anche.
query.result:
76 When we were there where the thigh 77 turns, at a point on the large of the hip, 78 the duke, with fatigue and with anguish,
79 turned the head where he had the haunches, 80 and clung to the skin like a man who climbs, 81 so that in hell I thought to return also.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 «Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale», 83 disse ’l maestro, ansando com’ uom lasso, 84 «conviensi dipartir da tanto male».
query.result: 82 “Take heed well, because for such stairs,” 83 said the master, panting like a weary man, 84 “it is fitting to depart from so much evil.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d’un sasso 86 e puose me in su l’orlo a sedere; 87 appresso porse a me l’accorto passo.

query.result:
88 I raised my eyes and thought I saw 89 Lucifer as I had left him, 90 and I saw his legs up, holding;
91 and if I then became troubled, 92 the great crowd thinks, that it does not see 93 what is that point that I had passed.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 «Lèvati sù», disse ’l maestro, «in piede: 95 la via è lunga e ’l cammino è malvagio, 96 e già il sole a mezza terza riede».
query.result: 94 “Raise yourself up,” said the master, “on foot: 95 the way is long and the path is wicked, 96 and already the sun at the middle third returns.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Non era camminata di palagio 98 là ’v’ eravam, ma natural burella 99 ch’avea mal suolo e di lume disagio.
query.result: 97 It was not a walk of palace 98 there where we were, but natural burella 99 that had bad ground and of light discomfort

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 «Prima ch’io de l’abisso mi divella, 101 maestro mio», diss’ io quando fui dritto, 102 «a trarmi d’erro un poco mi favella:
103 ov’ è la ghiaccia? e questi com’ è fitto 104 sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc’ ora, 105 da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?».
query.result:
100 "Before I tear myself from the abyss, 101 my master," I said when I was upright, 102 "to draw me out of error a little it speaks to me:
103 where is the ice? and how is this dense 104 so upside‑down? and how, in so little time, 105 from evening to morning has the sun made the journey?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Ed elli a me: «Tu imagini ancora 107 d’esser di là dal centro, ov’ io mi presi 108 al pel del vermo reo che ’l mondo fóra.
query.result: 106 And he to me: “You still imagine 107 to be beyond the centre, where I took 108 the skin of the guilty worm that the world were.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Di là fosti cotanto quant’ io scesi; 110 quand’ io mi volsi, tu passasti ’l punto 111 al qual si traggon d’ogne parte i pesi.

Please translate each line literally into English.
112 E se’ or sotto l’emisperio giunto 113 ch’è contraposto a quel che la gran secca 114 coverchia, e sotto ’l cui colmo consunto
115 fu l’uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca; 116 tu haï i piedi in su picciola spera 117 che l’altra faccia fa de la Giudecca.
query.result:
112 And if you are now under the hemisphere arrived 113 which is opposite to that which the great dry 114 covers, and under the whose full exhausted
115 was the man who was born and lived without sin; 116 you have the feet on a little hope 117 that the other face makes of the Giudecca.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Qui è da man, quando di là è sera; 119 e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo, 120 fitto è ancora sì come prim’ era.

Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo; 122 e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse, 123 per paura di lui fé del mar velo,
124 e venne a l’emisperio nostro; e forse 125 per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto 126 quella ch’appar di qua, e sù ricorse».
query.result:
121 From this side fell down from the sky; 122 and the earth, which first from here turned away, 123 for fear of him made a veil of the sea,
124 and came to our hemisphere; and perhaps 125 to flee he left here an empty place 126 that which appears from here, and up returned.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto 128 tanto quanto la tomba si distende, 129 che non per vista, ma per suono è noto
130 d’un ruscelletto che quivi discende 131 per la buca d’un sasso, ch’elli ha roso, 132 col corso ch’elli avvolge, e poco pende.
query.result:
127 Place is there down from remote Beelzebub 128 as much as the tomb extends, 129 that not by sight, but by sound is known
130 of a little stream that there descends 131 through the hole of a stone, which it has gnawed, 132 with the course that it wraps, and little hangs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso 134 intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo; 135 e sanza cura aver d’alcun riposo,
136 salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo, 137 tanto ch’i’ vidi de le cose belle 138 che porta ’l ciel, per un pertugio tondo.
query.result:
133 The leader and I through that hidden path 134 we entered to return into the bright world; 135 and without care having any rest,
136 we rose up, he first and I second, 137 so much that I saw the beautiful things 138 that the sky carries, through a round opening.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle.
query.result: 139 And then we went out to see again the stars.
